entry.title: Print Form Services Credential Migration: We’re Live and Auto-Provisioning!
entry.content:
Dear customers and partners,

As a sequel to my previous blog announcing this migration here: Simplifying Print Form Services Credentialling - SAP Community

We’re pleased to announce that our migration of credentials for Print Form Services (PFS) is now fully complete. From this point forward, new PFS credentials will be automatically provisioned — you no longer need to request or wait for manual issuance.

What this means for you

  • Seamless credential issuance: New accounts or services will receive PFS credentials automatically.

  • Minimal disruptions: All existing credentials remain valid and unaffected by the migration cut-over.

  • Improved stability and management: The fresh infrastructure delivers higher reliability and simplified administration.

Thank you!
We want to extend our heartfelt thanks to all of our customers and partners for your patience and support during this migration. Your cooperation made it possible for us to deliver this transition with minimal disruption and to enhance our services behind the scenes.

If you have any questions, notice any issues, or need assistance with your PFS credentials, please reach out to our support team and we’ll be glad to help. Thank you for your partnership and for continuing to trust us.

entry.title: Breakdown analysis for equipment with no start-up date in cloud public
entry.content:
Hello all...

I found that executing the Technical object breakdowns App in S4/Hana public cloud 2508 there are no results when the equipment start-up date is not filled up, also with multiple notifications in differente times. At soon as I put a date in that field in the equipment master data record I can see the results. According to the documentation I found, the report should consider the second notification as the start date of the report when the equipment start-up date is blank. I found the note 3198903 (Notifications not appearing in app "Technical Object Breakdowns" despite having Breakdown checkbox set - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition) and it explains the same. Is there something to configure or to set up to be able to get the analysis without that info? I appreciate any help in this matter.

Thank you,

Javier Gómez

entry.title: Drive more Business Value out of your SAP Public Cloud Solution Subscriptions.
entry.content:
If you are an SAP Public Cloud customer running solutions like SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba, etc., or you are a new SAP Business Suite customer running public cloud packages, I want to make you aware of a great capability included in SAP for Me to help drive more business value out of your SAP subscription.

SAP for Me includes the Customer Insights Dashboard. This tool analyzes the history of your support data, product portfolio, renewals, support contracts, system landscape, cases, and more. Within this dashboard, there is a great section that shows Cloud Functional Usage. In the following blogs below from my SAP colleague Swetlana, you can learn more about how to use this Cloud Functional Usage section in detail. I advise you to review them before you continue so you can follow the example that I will present shortly.

Functional Usage for your Public Cloud Products in Customer Insights reporting in SAP for Me

Functional Usage - Value Drivers and Peer Group Comparison

SAP for Me – Customer Insights Dashboard - Cloud Functional Usage

In this blog, I want to use the Cloud Functional Usage Report included in SAP for Me to give you a couple of recommendations to increase your business value from your SAP Public Cloud Subscription by focusing on the Value Drivers and relevant industry peer groups when you run different SAP Public Cloud Applications—in other words, to bring business value to your entire public cloud landscape.

In the following example below, imagine you are a live SAP customer with a public cloud landscape including subscriptions for: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Business Data Cloud (“SAP BDC” including Analytic Cloud and SAP Datasphere), and SAP BTP, or you may be a new SAP Business Suite Public Cloud customer as I discussed before.

Example - Live SAP customer with a public cloud landscape

In this example, you have already followed some of the recommendations provided in my last blog  for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, but now want to focus on increasing business value for the entire public cloud landscape.

First, you need to go to SAP for Me and select the Cloud Functional Usage Report. I suggest you quickly review the Usage History to view your solution capabilities, but I recommend adding the view by Product to make it simpler to identify in your landscape.

SAP for Me – Customer Insights Dashboard - Cloud Functional Usage – Usage History

With the product view, now you can look at the solution capabilities in your different SAP Product Subscriptions.

Cloud Functional Usage – Usage History view by Product

Per Swetlana’s previous blog explanations, you know that this view shows your current usage by solution capability for each specific subscribed product.

Now that you are looking at your usage, you can see the business impact, so you can now select the “Business Value” tab to focus on the value drivers and relevant industry peer groups. Here, I also recommend that you view the graphic by product.

SAP for Me – Customer Insights Dashboard - Cloud Functional Usage – Business Value

By doing so, you can now see the top 10 value drivers based on the most used solution capabilities in your landscape.

Cloud Functional Usage – Business Value – view by Product

You now have a great option to render this graphic by specific value driver(s), by product(s), or by both, which will give you plenty of flexibility to look at business outcomes. Let’s imagine you want to impact the reduction of finance costs in your organization to make your finance team more productive and cost-effective. You can select that value driver and look at your current usage in your company.

Cloud Functional Usage – Business Value – filtered by Value Driver “Reduce finance cost”

You can see here that this value driver is impacted by a couple of products including: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Finance), SAP Analytics Cloud (SAP BDC), and Cash & Treasury Add-on (Finance).

You also see that there are plenty of solution capabilities not used (in gray), which you can evaluate to see if you can start using them to help drive more business value. However, what makes this report really useful is that you can look at your usage intensity or lack of usage by comparing it with your relevant industry peer group. This means you can benchmark your usage with your industry peer group to gain some insights on what other SAP customers are doing.

Cloud Functional Usage – Business Value – selected by non-used solution capabilities in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

In the above example, I selected the 30 non-used solution capabilities in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, as I really want to impact the reduction of financial cost. When doing this, I see that my industry peer group is highly using 9 out of the 30 capabilities, moderately using 4 out of the 30 capabilities, and low using 17 out of the 30 capabilities.

So this helps you benchmark your usage with your industry peer group. Here it will make sense to see what are those 9 capabilities that I can evaluate to implement to help drive more business value. So, if I select the 9 capabilities in the industry footprint graph, I can now see the details below.

Cloud Functional Usage – Business Value – selected by highly used solution capabilities in relevant industry peer group in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

If I then select the solution capability “Financial Reporting,” I get an overview of the functionality on how it contributes to the value driver. I also get additional information, such as the Fiori apps that I can start using or activate to benefit from this functionality.

Solution Capability – Financial Reporting

I can then click on all 33 relevant Fiori apps and go to the SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library to see the apps.

SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library filtered by Solution Capability – Financial Reporting

From there, I can get all information from the app, such as product information and implementation, and I can then check directly in my system landscape.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition – Looking at Fiori App “Display Cash Flow – Indirect Method”

I can then go back and look at the other components—like the Cash & Treasury Add-on—and compare them with the relevant industry peer group that I potentially should be considering. I see that the Financial Risk Management (which I don’t use) solution capability has a moderate usage among relevant industry peers, so I should evaluate its applicability.

Cloud Functional Usage – Business Value – selected by non-used solution capabilities in Cash & Treasury Add-on

I can click again on the solution capability to look at impacts, view the Fiori Application Library, and review the apps in my system as I did before.

Solution Capability – Financial Risk Management

This time, instead of looking at each app, I will click on the SAP Fiori Apps grouped by end user role “Treasury Risk Manager” to see the overall business role in the SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library.

SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library filtered by Solution Capability – Financial Risk Management – Treasury Risk Manager Role

You could also look at this using a list view or try the new list view that has significantly improved how information is rendered.

SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library New List View filtered by Solution Capability – Financial Risk Management

From here, you can go to your system landscape and then look to include the SAP business role you are not using, “Treasury Risk Manager.”

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition – Activating “Treasury Risk Manager Role”

Now, let's take a look at SAP SuccessFactors. I go back to the Cloud Functional Usage Report, but this time I will filter by Product.

Cloud Functional Usage – Business Value – filtered by Product “SAP SuccessFactors”

Here you can now see the Top 10 value drivers for SAP SuccessFactors. Of course, you can select specific components to evaluate specific areas of improvement.

If I focus now only on SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, I can see that there are 4 solution capabilities I am not using which have a high impact on many value drivers.

Cloud Functional Usage – Business Value – selected by non-used solution capabilities in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central

If I am very conservative and only focus on the high usage in the relevant industry peer group, I see that I could impact many value drivers by focusing on “Position Management” solution capability.

Cloud Functional Usage – Business Value – selected by highly used solution capability in relevant industry peer group in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central

Like in the other example, I can click on the solution capability to review the details.

Solution Capability – Position Management

And then go to SAP SuccessFactors to activate the solution capability.

SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central – Activating Position Management

And start using it in your system.

SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central – Using Position Management

I could continue the exploration to the SAP BDC components (SAP Analytics Cloud & SAP Datasphere), see below and run another cycle as the ones I presented above.

Cloud Functional Usage – Business Value – filtered by Product “SAP BDC – SAP Analytics Cloud & SAP Datasphere”

I hope this Cloud Functional Usage information included in SAP for ME provides you with some ideas for your new projects, new business rollouts, or new business requirements for your entire public cloud landscape. Keep in mind that solution capabilities are expanding from traditional functional scope to also include SAP Business AI, so SAP will continue to add more in this area. Remember, this is not the only tool that can be used; SAP has other tools such as SAP Signavio, SAP WalkMe, SAP LeanIX, and SAP Cloud ALM that can be used in tandem to help drive more business value from your SAP subscription. I encourage you to discuss these points with your SAP Customer Success Manager, SAP Account Executive, or SAP Partner. They may be able to provide you with additional recommendations and guidance.

Your insights and opinions are valuable, so please don't hesitate to contribute by commenting on this blog.

Follow us via @SAP and #S4HANA or follow @Marco_Valencia (SAP Business Suite Customer Success Management).

entry.title: Re: Onboarding 1.0 Decommissioning Procedure & FAQ
entry.content:
I also want to call out an excellent question that came up this week in discussions with a customer, and one I wanted to note here as well in a comment. Please see my revised blog above.

What happens to my E-Verify Cases through Onboarding 1.0?

While your E-Verify Cases will no longer be accessible through the Onboarding 1.0 interface after decommissioning, you can still export the "E-Verify Summary Form" to have a record of the E-Verify Cases created during Onboarding 1.0's tenure. This Form should be part of your Document Export and Retention functions as part of decommissioning, listed above.

What happens to any outstanding or open E-Verify Cases through Onboarding 1.0, when the product is decommissioned?

There may be some circumstances where there are E-Verify Cases that are still open during Onboarding 1.0's decommissioning and afterwards, and that cannot be acted on as they are pending either government (DHS, SSA, or both) action. For these outstanding E-Verify Cases, please generate a Report within Onboarding 1.0 for these Cases. SAP SuccessFactors, as your E-Verify Web Service Provider, can continue to provide updates to you through a Customer Support Case.

We anticipate this should be a rare situation in the event customers have successfully been able to reduce and migrate their E-Verify activity over to Onboarding or another solution prior to the decommissioning.

entry.title: PLR 2025 - Correções retroativas de imposto
entry.content:
Olá pessoal, 

Acabamos de lançar uma solução importante para lidar com o desafio tributário da Participação nos Lucros e Resultados (PLR) de 2025, permitindo que a folha de pagamento corrija o pagamento de imposto após a publicação tardia da tabela oficial de impostos pelo Governo Brasileiro. 

Desafio de 2025 

A publicação tardia da tabela oficial de impostos do PLR para 2025 trouxe as seguintes consequências: 

  • Processamento com Tabela Anterior: Empresas utilizaram a tabela do ano anterior, gerando um cálculo de imposto equivocado 
  • Publicação Retroativa: A nova tabela foi publicada com validade retroativa 
  • Impacto nos Funcionários: Colaboradores pagaram mais impostos do que o devido 
  • Autorização Governamental: Governo autorizou empresas a reembolsarem os valores pagos em excesso 

Nossa Solução 

Desenvolvemos uma solução que identifica e corrige retroativamente os impostos sobre PLR pagos em excesso durante 2025. O sistema utiliza novas rubricas para calcular as diferenças e processar os reembolsos devidos aos colaboradores, garantindo conformidade com as autorizações governamentais. 

A solução está disponível através das seguintes SAP Notes: 

  • 3672102 - Retroactive PLR Tax Corrections: Creation of New Wage Types 
  • 3669244 - BRIR - Retroactive PLR Tax Corrections  for 2025
  • 3681233 - eSocial - S-1010 - Adjustments for /IOP and /ROP wage types 

Novas Rubricas 

O sistema introduz três novas rubricas que trabalham em conjunto: 

  • /IRP - Indicador reembolso PLR: Rubrica adicionada manualmente no infotipo 0015 – Pagamento complementar para acionar o cálculo retroativo 
  • /IOP - IRRF PLR desc. em excesso: Indica o valor pago em excesso 
  • /ROP - Reembolso IRRF sobre PLR: Reembolso do valor pago em excesso 

Como Funciona 

Acionamento Manual: Para colaboradores que não receberão mais pagamentos de PLR em 2025 o acionamento é manual 

  • Adicione a rubrica /IRP ao último período pagamento incorreto no infotipo 0015 
  • Sistema calculará automaticamente os valores em excesso 
  • Reembolso será processado na próxima folha 

Ajuste Automático: Para funcionários com pagamentos futuros de PLR no ano de 2025, o ajuste é automático 

  • Nenhuma ação manual necessária 
  • Sistema ajusta automaticamente no próximo pagamento de PLR 
  • Ambas as rubricas, /IOP e /ROP, aparecem no mesmo período se a compensação for insuficiente 

Transferência e PLR em Empresas Anteriores: Para empregados transferidos entre empresas 

  • Adicione /IRP ao último pagamento de PLR de cada empresa afetada 
  • Trate a empresa atual da mesma forma que nos cenários acima 
  • O dinheiro pago em excesso de todos os PLRs calculados de forma incorreta serão reembolsados no próximo pagamento 

Considerações Importantes 

  • Aplicação Específica para 2025: Esta solução foi desenvolvida especificamente para lidar com o atraso da tabela de PLR de 2025 
  • Cálculo Anual: Impostos de PLR são calculados anualmente, considerando todos os pagamentos do ano 
  • Uso Inteligente do Gatilho: Adicione /IRP apenas quando não houver mais pagamentos de PLR esperados 

Com essas atualizações, você garantirá que seus sistemas estejam em conformidade com as exigências governamentais, promovendo eficiência e tratamento justo aos funcionários afetados pela situação excepcional de 2025. 

Gostou desse post? 

Dê um Like e compartilhe o conteúdo com seus colegas. 

Fiquem à vontade para deixar um feedback, comentário ou pergunta sobre este Blog post no espaço abaixo. E não esqueçam de seguir a tag HCM Payroll Brazil na SAP Community para ficarem ligados nas últimas notícias. 

Um abraço, 
Ramiro dos Santos Manoel 
Time de HCM Brasil

entry.title: Re: Transporting Deleted Teams from Test to Production in...
entry.content:
@OmPan 

Unfortunately, SAC transport mechanisms don't handle deletions.

The transport process in SAP Analytics Cloud is like this, on a tenant when we create or update objects we can create an export and collect these objects and when we import them they get created or updated in the target tenant. The process only creates or updates objects, and there is no way to capture a deleted object in a transport. 

Unlike ABAP transports, which capture objects marked for deletion and can replicate object deletions across systems, SAC transports are additive only. 

What this means for you: The Teams you deleted in Test won't automatically be removed in Production through a transport. You'll need to delete them separately in Production.

Recommended approach for future housekeeping: Since you're dealing with multiple Teams, I'd suggest using the SAC User & Team Provisioning (SCIM) API to delete the teams programmatically across tenants. 

Refer this blog for detailed information on using the API, https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-analytics-cloud-user-and-team-provisioning-api-hands-on-video-tutorials/ba-p/13510017

entry.title: Rehire process with ONB 2.0 and mini EC
entry.content:
Hi,

Has anyone implemented ONB 2.0 with mini EC for rehire process? As per SAP documentation, rehire process is not supported with mini EC. I am looking experiences from projects that have successfully gone live for Rehire process with ONB 2.0+mini EC.

We are thinking of treating rehire as a new hire in ONB but in this case, we are having below roadblocks:

1. We are planning to store external HRIS employee number in Person ID external field. However, every rehire [for that matter hire as well] will have a new user ID created [as per SF number range], leading a situation wherein Person ID external [External HRIS Employee Number] and User ID both being different. This wouldn't impact us for ONB, RCM scope but as we expand the scope in the future with talent modules, this will create some challenges [e.g. Performance history, learning history will be on two different user IDs, etc.].

2.  Because ONB rehire match functionality cannot be used with mini-EC, we are unable to meet business requirements around bringing past employment data into ONB or RCM such as Rehire eligibility. We are planning to build a new interface either with external HRIS application or SF mini EC [we will have to bring termination history] to bring rehire check value [and other attributes] into RCM.

Thanks in advance!

Regards,

Amol

SAP S/4HANA

entry.title: How Difficult Is the SAP ERP Consultant Role Today?
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I wanted to start a discussion about the real level of difficulty in working as an SAP ERP consultant. The role keeps evolving, and I’m curious how others in the community see it today.

From my own experience in SAP FICO, the job definitely requires a mix of technical skills, business understanding, and continuous learning — especially with S/4HANA, Fiori, and new cloud-related changes. It’s a demanding role, but also one that brings a lot of reward and growth.

I’d like to hear your thoughts:

  • What aspects of SAP consulting do you find the most challenging?
  • In your view, is the role becoming more difficult with newer SAP technologies, or are tools actually making things easier?
  • How do you keep up with the constant learning required?
  • What advice would you give to someone starting their SAP journey?

    Looking forward to hearing different perspectives from the community.

entry.title: How to dynamically split comma-separated values into multiple rows in SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
I am working in SAP Datasphere (Data Builder – Graphical View) and I have a column that contains comma-separated values inside a single row. Example:

ID

Observee(s)

19195

0039270, 0040932, 00051689

43400

00055233

121461

NULL

My requirement is to dynamically split these comma-separated values into individual rows, like this:

ID

Observee

19195

0039270

19195

0040932

19195

00051689

43400

00055233

I need a solution that is 

Dynamic (not limited to a fixed number of values like 5 or 10)

 Works in SAP Datasphere (Graphical View OR HANA SQL

Works even when:

  • number of comma-separated values varies per row
  • values sometimes contain spaces
  • column type is NVARCHAR
  • JSON_TABLE or STRING_TO_TABLE are not supported
  • Recursion is not enabled in Datasphere SQL View 
  • So far, I tried:
  • JSON_TABLE() → not supported
  • STRING_TO_TABLE() → not supported
  • Recursive CTE → not allowed inside Data Builder SQL View
  • Regular expression functions → no REGEXP_SUBSTR in Graphical View
  • Calculated Columns → no built-in SPLIT or explode function

Is there any recommended Datasphere pattern for splitting CSV string fields into multiple records?

Is this possible in:

  • Graphical View (Projection, Aggregation, Calculated Column, etc.)
    or
  • SQL View using functions supported by SAP HANA Cloud?

If someone can provide either:

A working SQL example

or

A correct modeling approach in Datasphere

entry.title: 🇹🇷 Foundations of AI applications with the SAP HANA Cloud (Istanbul, TR)
entry.content:
Please note that registration is now closed, as of November 15, 12:00 pm TRT, due to reaching the registration limit. All registrations received after the initial limit of 25 will be considered for the waiting list. A confirmation email will be sent to those who have successfully registered before the event.

This SAP CodeJam event focuses on SAP HANA Cloud for AI Applications, covering topics such as machine learning, Vectors, and Knowledge Graphs. You don't need to have any background in the topic, but you should have a lot of curiosity and some basic programming skills!

This is a free in-person event and is planned for Saturday, December 13, in Istanbul, Türkiye 🇹🇷 from 10:00 to 16:00 TRT (UTC+3). The event's language and content will be in English. 

The event is being hosted by Sovos at
Öz sokak No: 19/10 😧 45 Gold Plaza, Altayçeşme,
34843 Maltepe/İstanbul

Please note that space is limited, as we can only accommodate 25 attendees.

By the end of the session, you’ll have built examples that demonstrate how SAP HANA Cloud can serve as a versatile back-end for modern Artificial Intelligence applications:

  • Leverage the SAP HANA Vector Engine for high‑dimensional embeddings—building a vector store that supports semantic similarity search.
  • Implement Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)  to enrich generative AI outputs with precise, up-to-date data.
  • Model and Query a Knowledge Graph inside SAP HANA using RDF triples to extract semantic relationships.
  • Integrate HANA with LangChain to build AI apps that orchestrate prompt workflows, execute database statements, and navigate knowledge graphs—all directly from Python, in this case.

entry.title: Sydney Stammtisch Recap Nov '25 (Mastering SAP vs. Tech Ed On Tour)
entry.content:
Usually our #Sydney #Stammtisch events are planned a few weeks in advance (I plan ahead to a fault) but this one ended up being somewhat impromptu.  We had what I thought was our last event of 2025 a couple of weeks ago.  As Mastering SAP often organise great social events as part of their conference (this year a Tech Ed On Tour Event no less) I thought that we shouldn't 'compete' with whatever they had planned.  Well, it turned out that there wasn't an official social event in the calendar so when@AnnePetteroe reached out to us we were already open to the idea of holding a (possibly unprecedented) fifth Stammtisch of 2025.

It was a bit of a scramble but @jeff_t managed to line up a great venue - Sydney Pumphouse - which was very close to the conference venue and close to where most visitors were staying.  We had a great crowd of men & women, both on the younger side and on the slightly less young side.  We had native born Australians alongside people from pretty much every continent (ish).  We had people with blue beards, and people without blue beards (I would say that the latter were in the majority).

Debra from Mastering used the 5mins that she had free on the eve of the conference to come and meet everyone, which was awesome.

As we get more and more people attending Stammtisch my photos seem to do less and less justice to the event.  It was quite dark inside and so I mainly grabbed a few snaps on the terrace.  I thought there were at least 50 attendees but I saw @thomas_jung say on YouTube that there were '70-80' people there, and I wouldn't like to argue with Thomas!

Please feel free to add your own photos in the comments.

A real highlight was the three students who showed having seen @josh_bentley on You Tube shorts mentioning Stammtisch.  Tamer put in a call to someone at Mastering SAP to get them access to the conference somehow, which was just awesome of him. 

It was a great start to what turned out to be a great conference and I do wonder whether we should repeat the same format next year.  Tuesday night is a tough night to get locals out, and we missed many fly-ins because they were due to arrive too late or because their flights got delayed by strong winds.  We might have got more locals if we had given more notice. We could go for the end of Day 1 of the conference, but then there may be other events then (like the awesome RevTrac drinks).

What do you think?

Certainly no-one should be booking flights to Sydney for Mastering SAP Collaborate 2026 without checking with us first 😉

Thanks so much to everyone who came!

entry.title: Quickly Deploy a Sample CAP Application to BTP
entry.content:
Prerequisites

Before you deploy your sample SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) app to SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), ensure you have the following in place:

  1. BTP Account (Trial or Paid)
    You’ll need a BTP global account with a sub-account in the Cloud Foundry environment.

    • You can register for a free trial at the SAP website. BTP Trial

  2. Development Environment: SAP Business Application Studio or VS Code alternative + CLI tools & MBT 

    • If using Business Application Studio, follow SAP’s onboarding tutorial: “Set Up SAP Business Application Studio for Development”. Setup Business Application Studio

    • Otherwise you may use VS Code (or another IDE) with the following command-line tools:

      • Cloud Foundry CLI (cf CLI) – Install instructions here: CF CLI

      • Cloud MTA Build Tool (mbt) – Install and usage information here: MBT

    • Make sure you’ve configured your CLI to target your BTP subaccount/space (cf api, cf login, cf target). CLI API & Login

  3. HANA DB Instance (or Trial) for your DB
    Your CAP app will typically require a database backend.

    • Get started with the HANA Cloud trial using this tutorial:  HANA Trial

After completing all the prerequisites we can start build the application

Start a Terminal in you IDE of choice

generate the project

cds init bookshop --add sample

Add hana, mta, xsuaa and workzone

cds add hana,mta,xsuaa,workzone --for production

run npm install in all the applications, the sample bookshop has 2 Fiori Elements applications that we'll need to run npm i in their folder as well as in the project folder

cd app/admin-books
npm i
cd ../browse
npm i
cd ../..
npm i

now we can build the project

mbt build

if all goes well then we'll get an mtar file inside the mta_archive folder

before deploying we'll need to make sure that we're logged into cloud foundry

cf login

now we deploy

cf deploy mta_archives/*.mtar

and that is it you should now have a CAP service and 2 fiori elements applications deployed on BTP.

You can then create an instance of Work Zone and surface the application through it or build applications that use the cap application as its backend (This is what I intend to do in upcoming blogs)

entry.title: Identity Access Governance - Understanding Authorization Policies
entry.content:
We have often seen business scenarios where requirement is to restrict the Access/Role search in IAG  Access Request to specific list of roles for defined set of users. For e.g. Users in country/company code X should only see the roles for country/company code X in the Access request form to request.

In GRC Access Controls, we achieve this requirement from traditional authorizations/roles concept and role search functionality

IAG offers the concept of defining Authorization Policies to achieve this goal

 

Overview

Authorization policies determine which roles, applications, or business roles end users can search and request in the Access Request application. Administrators can configure these policies in the Authorization Policy app to control search visibility and request capability

 

Authorizations for Access Request

When performing a role search in the Access Request app, results may be restricted based on authorization policies. Administrators define which Access objects, Business Roles, or Applications/Systems users can search and request.

 

Policy Types for Role Search

Access

  • Action: Request Access
  • Description: Allows assigned users to request access for all Access items defined by the authorization object attributes.
  • Authorization Object Attributes:
    • Name
    • Application
    • Application Type
    • Access Type
    • Business Process
    • Business Subprocess

Business Role

  • Action: Request Access
  • Description: Allows assigned users to request access for all Business Roles defined by the authorization object attributes.
  • Authorization Object Attributes:
    • Name
    • Business Process
    • Business Subprocess
    • Criticality

Application/System

  • Action: Request Access
  • Description: Allows assigned users to request access for all Applications/Systems defined by the authorization object attributes.
  • Authorization Object Attributes:
    • Application
    • Application Type

 

Application - Authorization Policy under Administration section

Flowchart

 

  1. Policy Set - Container of multiple policies of a specific Policy type (for e,g, Access/Access Risk/Business Role etc.). Users are assigned to Policy sets based on User attributes.
  2. Policies - Policies are maintained within policy set and can be activated/deactivated based on need. Each policy contains Authorizations which further contains
    1.   "Actions"  (for e,g, Request Access in policy set type Access and Business Role)
    2.  "Access/Business Roles" based on attributes.

 

Screenshots

 

Authorization Policy App

 

Creation of Policy Set

 

Creation of Policy

 

Configuration of Authorizations and Access/Business role based on attributes

 

Defining Access

 

Defining Users based on attributes

 

Conclusion

Once policy is activated, Access and Business roles will be filtered based on defined authorization policies.

Standard SAP documentation - Authorization Policies in Identity Access Governance

entry.title: Fixing IGS Connection Issues After SID Change in S/4HANA Migration
entry.content:
When migrating an SAP S/4HANA system and changing the System ID (SID), you might encounter issues with graphical charts in certain transactions. A common example is Transaction DB02, which shows database performance and space statistics.

After migration, executing DB02 may result in :  IGS not available (RC=1), Charts not available

Root Cause
The Internet Graphics Service (IGS) is responsible for rendering charts in SAP GUI. It communicates via an RFC destination named IGS_RFC_DEST. When the SID changes during migration, this RFC destination still points to the old SID, causing the connection to fail.

Symptoms

  • Charts in DB02 are missing.
  • RFC destination IGS_RFC_DEST fails the connection test.
  • Error message: IGS not available (RC=1).

Solution: Update RFC Destination
Step 1: Go to Transaction SM59

Navigate to RFC Destinations.
Search for IGS_RFC_DEST (Type: TCP/IP Connection).

Step 2: Test the Connection

Perform a Connection Test.
It will fail because the program name and gateway details are incorrect.

Step 3: Update the RFC Parameters
Modify the following fields:

  • Program Name: IGS.<SID> (Replace <SID> with your new system ID.)
  • Gateway Host: Set this to the CI (Central Instance) server host of the new SID.
  • Gateway Service: sapgw<nn> (Replace <nn> with the instance number of the CI.)

Step 4: Save and Test Again

Run the Connection Test. It should now succeed.

Step 5: Verify in DB02

Execute DB02 again. Charts should now be visible.

Additional Tips

  • After any SID change, review all RFC destinations in SM59.
  • Check other services like SAP Gateway and IGS to ensure they are running.
  • If you use load-balanced systems, verify the gateway host points to the correct application server.

entry.title: SAP AIDevCon 2025: A Day That Redefined AI Innovation
entry.content:
What an absolute triumph yesterday was! The SAP AIDevCon 2025 event on November 8th wasn't just another conference; it was a powerful convergence of ideas, talent, and technology that truly demonstrated the revolutionary potential of Business AI.

The air in the venue was charged with incredible energy and vibrancy. We saw over 50+ passionate participants from more than 26+ diverse corporates and 3 key Indian universities come together. The goal was simple but profound: to not just talk about AI, but to build it.

Igniting Innovation: The Hands-on Experience

The day kicked off with invaluable networking—the kind that sparks future projects—followed by an inspiring keynote address from our VP, Head of APAC. This set the stage for the true excitement: the hands-on experience.

Our participants didn't just attend sessions; they became builders. They immersed themselves in cutting-edge SAP BTP AI services, specifically using:

  • SAP Build for powerful low-code process automation.

  • Document AI to intelligently process unstructured business documents.

  • Translation Hub to instantly break down language barriers in applications.

The highlight was the intensive hackathon. Our audience, a perfect blend of industry experts and bright university students, worked in fierce yet collaborative teams. The atmosphere was one of positive vibes and shared goals, where they had to train, exhibit, and deliver industry-ready prototypes.

Breakthrough Prototypes: Solving Real Problems

The solutions developed were not academic exercises—they were direct answers to critical business challenges. The teams built phenomenal prototypes that showcased the speed and scale possible with SAP BTP AI, focusing on real-world impact:

  1. Dispute Management: Creating smart solutions to automate and accelerate complex financial and operational dispute resolution.

  2. Piracy Protection: Leveraging AI to build robust, automated systems for safeguarding digital assets and intellectual property.

  3. Wellbeing: Developing AI-driven applications to enhance employee and user well-being through proactive insights and personalised support.

This entire day was a masterclass in learning, teamwork, and execution, all driven by the powerful capabilities of SAP Business Technology Platform.

Gratitude for Our Ecosystem of Heroes

A monumental event like this is only possible because of a dedicated community. A huge and sincere thank you goes out to:

  • Our incredible mentors and volunteers whose guidance transformed ideas into working code.

  • All the brilliant participants for bringing their enthusiasm and skill.

  • The SAP Leadership for championing the vision of an AI-first future.

  • The unsung heroes in IT, Security, and Admin, and each and every hero behind the scenes, whose seamless work made the entire event feel effortless.

entry.title: Re: MDG Consolidation process to trigger from Mulesoft
entry.content: Hi Markus, Thanks much for your response. But here we are trying to auto-trigger our Consolidation process in MDG with the incoming messages from Mulesoft. Offcourse, we want to use the SOAP message to trigger it, not using any file. I was looking for something in case if someone like you(experts) would have seen it in any customer's implementation. Thanks.

entry.title: خمسة أسباب تجعل وحدة المبيعات والتوزيع في "الساب" في قلب كل شركة
entry.content:
عندما يبدأ الناس في التعرف على نظام "الساب"، غالبًا ما يتبادر إلى ذهنهم وحدة المالية أو وحدة إدارة المشتريات. وبالطبع، كلاهما حيوي. ولكن ما هو الرابط الذي يجمع كل هذه الأجزاء معًا؟ ما هو المحرك الذي يدفع عجلة العمل حقًا؟

إنها وحدة المبيعات والتوزيع.

تخيل الأمر بهذه الطريقة: لا يمكن لأي شركة أن تستمر وتنمو إذا لم تبع أي شيء. وحدة المبيعات والتوزيع هي "القلب النابض" الذي يضخ أهم شيئين لبقاء الشركة: طلبات العملاء والأموال.

😂😂" طبعًا، كل مستشار وحدة ما، سيقول إن الوحدة التي يعمل فيها هي قلب "الساب

!أنا مستشار مبيعات؛ لذا فالأمر واضح

إليك خمسة أسباب تجعل وحدة المبيعات والتوزيع هي محور كل شيء.

 

البوابة الرئيسية لكل عميل 

لا شيء يحدث في الشركة حتى يقرر العميل أن يشتري. وحدة المبيعات والتوزيع هي "البوابة الرسمية" التي تستقبل هذا القرار. كل طلب بيع، كل عرض سعر، وكل وعد بتقديم خدمة للعميل يبدأ من هنا.

 

 تخبر المخزن بما يجب عليه فعله

طلب البيع هو مجرد بيانات في النظام حتى يغادر المنتج المخزن فعليًا. وهنا يكمن الاتصال الأول. في اللحظة التي يتم فيها إنشاء طلب بيع في وحدة المبيعات والتوزيع، فإنها ترسل رسالة فورية إلى فريق إدارة اللوجستيات والمخازن (أي وحدتي إدارة المشتريات وإدارة المخازن) تقول:

"انتبهوا! اذهبوا إلى الرف د-3، جهزوا 30 كرتونة من المنتج (س)، قوموا بتغليفها، واستعدوا لشحنها إلى عنوان هذا العميل."

بدون وحدة المبيعات والتوزيع التي تعطي هذه الأوامر، سيبقى المخزن مجرد مبنى كبير مليء بالبضائع التي لا تعرف إلى أين تذهب.

 

 تضمن أن الشركة تتحصل على أموالها

هذا هو الاتصال الثاني والأهم. بعد أن يؤكد فريق المخزن أن "البضاعة قد تم شحنها"، تلتفت وحدة المبيعات والتوزيع فورًا وترسل رسالة إلى فريق المالية. هذه الرسالة هي الفاتورة. والرسالة تقول:

"مرحبًا يا فريق المالية! لقد بعنا بضاعة بقيمة 20,000 درهم لهذا العميل، وهي الآن في الطريق إليه. من فضلكم، اذهبوا الآن وقوموا بتحصيل هذا المبلغ."

هكذا تتحول عملية "البيع" إلى "أموال نقدية في البنك". وحدة المبيعات والتوزيع هي الجسر الذي يحول "توصيل المنتج" إلى "إيرادات حقيقية" للشركة.

 

 العقل المدبر وراء تسعيرة المنتج

لماذا يحصل عميل في الدار البيضاء على خصم 10% بينما يدفع عميل آخر في الرباط السعر كاملاً؟ لماذا يوجد عرض "اشترِ قطعة واحصل على الثانية مجانًا" في نهاية هذا الأسبوع فقط؟

هذا ليس سحرًا؛ إنها آلية التسعير في وحدة المبيعات والتوزيع. يقوم مستشار المبيعات والتوزيع ببناء كل هذه القواعد والشروط المعقدة. وبمجرد إدخال الطلب، يقوم النظام تلقائيًا بحساب السعر النهائي، والضرائب، والخصومات، وتكاليف الشحن. إنه العقل المركزي الذي يضمن أن السعر صحيح 100% لكل عميل، وفي كل طلب.

 

 تجيب على الأسئلة الكبرى للمدير العام

نظرًا لأن كل عملية بيع، صغيرة كانت أم كبيرة، تمر عبر وحدة المبيعات والتوزيع، فإنها تحتفظ بأثمن كنز للشركة: البيانات. عندما يريد المدير العام وفريق الإدارة معرفة وضع الشركة، فإنهم يطرحون أسئلة كبيرة، ووحدة المبيعات والتوزيع هي التي تمتلك الإجابات:

"ما هو منتجنا الأكثر مبيعًا هذا الشهر؟"

"من هم أكبر 10 عملاء لدينا من حيث الإيرادات؟"

"ما هي المدينة أو المنطقة الجغرافية التي تحقق أعلى مبيعات؟"

كل التقارير التي تقود استراتيجية العمل وتساعد على اتخاذ القرار (ماذا نبيع أكثر؟ أين نفتتح فرعًا جديدًا؟) تستمد بياناتها مباشرة من وحدة المبيعات والتوزيع.

كمستشار وحدة مبيعات يمكن أن أقول بكل ثقة أن هذه الوحدة هي الرابط الحيوي الذي يجمع مكونات أي شركة، نشاطها الرئيسي يرتكز على عمليات البيع.

entry.title: What Does an SAP Sales Consultant Actually Do?
entry.content:
You see the job title SAP SD Consultant everywhere. But what does that person actually do all day? If you ask a consultant, they’ll probably say something like “I configure the system” or “I manage the Order-to-Cash process.” Which is true, but doesn’t really explain what the job feels like.

In simple terms, the SAP SD (Sales and Distribution) module covers everything from a customer’s order to delivery and billing. The SD consultant is the one who builds, maintains, and fixes that whole flow. You’re not a salesperson. You’re the person making sure the company can sell, without chaos.

So what do you really do? Here’s what the job looks like in real life.

  1. Understanding the business: 

    Before you touch SAP, you need to know what the business actually needs. That means talking to sales managers, warehouse guys, finance teams — the people doing the real work.

    You don’t ask, “What do you want in SAP?”
     You ask, “How do you work?” and “What’s going wrong?”

    Example: The sales manager says, “We need to give a 10% discount to any customer in Casablanca who buys more than 50 cases of our new soda.”  Now you ask the real questions: 50 cases per order or per month? All customers or specific ones? What if they return 10?

    That’s the real detective work.

  2. Building it in SAP:

    Once you understand the rule, you go into the system and make it real. This is configuration! not coding. You’re turning business logic into SAP logic.

    Example: You create a condition record that tells the system: If the customer is from Casablanca, the product is “New Soda,” and the quantity is over 50, apply a 10% discount.

  3.  When SAP can’t do it: 

    Sometimes the business wants something too specific for SAP’s standard features. That’s when you write a “functional spec”, a document for the developer explaining exactly what needs to be built.

    Example: They want a report that emails all orders with that 10% discount every day at 5 PM. You describe the layout, the data sources (tables like VBAK, KNA1, KONV), and the logic behind it. Then the developer codes it.

  4.  Testing everything: 

    After you build or the developer finishes, you test it. And you test it again. You make sure every possible scenario behaves as expected.

    Example:

    60 cases, Casablanca → Discount applies.
    40 cases, Casablanca → No discount.
    60 cases, Rabat → No discount.
  5. Supporting users: 

    Once the system goes live, things break. Orders get stuck, deliveries fail, prices go crazy. That’s when users call you.

    Example: A sales clerk says an order is blocked: “Credit limit exceeded.” You check the credit data, find out finance hasn’t cleared a payment, explain it, and unblock the issue.

    That’s day-to-day life.
  6. Teaching people: 

    You also train users and write simple guides: screenshots, short steps, nothing fancy.

    Example: After you create that discount report, you show sales managers how to open it, read it, and use it. Then you leave them with a short guide.

So, what’s the job really?

An SAP SD Consultant is the bridge between business and system. You understand how the company sells, then make SAP follow that logic. You listen, you build, you test, you fix, and you teach.
That’s it. That’s the real job!

entry.title: SuccessFactors Sales Performance Module
entry.content:
Driving Revenue Excellence with SAP Sales Performance Management

In today’s competitive landscape, organizations are increasingly relying on intelligent tools to optimize sales performance and align sales teams with business objectives. The SAP Sales Performance Management (SPM) module empowers companies to design, manage, and analyze their sales strategies with precision.

1. What is SAP SPM?
SAP SPM is an integrated solution that automates and streamlines key processes such as sales incentive management, territory and quota planning, and performance analytics. By eliminating manual processes and data silos, it ensures that sales teams stay motivated and aligned with company goals.

2. Core Capabilities:

  • Incentive Compensation Management: Automate commission calculations, ensure transparency, and reduce payment disputes.

  • Territory and Quota Planning: Optimize sales coverage and set achievable, data-driven quotas.

  • Analytics and Insights: Monitor performance in real time with dashboards that drive accountability and improvement.

3. Business Impact:
Organizations using SAP SPM report improved sales productivity, higher motivation, and faster decision-making. Integrating the module with SAP SuccessFactors or SAP CX solutions further enhances end-to-end visibility — from people performance to customer success.

4. The Future of Sales Enablement:
With built-in AI and predictive analytics, SAP SPM is evolving beyond automation to provide foresight — helping leaders forecast trends, identify performance gaps, and model the impact of incentive plan changes before implementation.

In summary, SAP Sales Performance Management transforms sales operations into a data-driven, transparent, and motivating ecosystem — driving both top-line growth and team engagement.

entry.title: Re: How to configure automatic G/L account selection for...
entry.content:
Hi seunabati,
As you explain when posting outgoing or incoming payments, after i choose bank account even though you’ve already set up the reconciliation account and linked it to the bank account. Please follow the step by step configuration as i show you below.

1. Bank Account Master Data (Manage Bank Accounts App)
In the bank account master record, you can assign:Main Bank Reconciliation Account (already done in your case). Payment Subaccounts for Incoming and Outgoing flows. These subaccounts are what the system uses to automatically post to the correct GL when you create payments.

2. Assign Payment Methods
Go to Manage Payment Methods for Company Code.
For each payment method (e.g., wire transfer, check, SEPA), assign: The Bank Account. The GL Subaccount (Incoming or Outgoing). This ensures that when you select a payment method, the system knows which GL account to hit.

3. Automatic Account Determination
In SSCUI (Self-Service Configuration UI) for Bank Accounting, check: Define House Banks and Account IDs → link the bank account ID to the reconciliation account and subaccounts. Define Posting Rules → specify which GL account is used for debit (outgoing) and credit (incoming).

4. Payment Transactions
When you post an outgoing payment, the system looks at: The payment method + bank account ID → derives the outgoing subaccount. When you post an incoming payment, the same logic applies but points to the incoming subaccount.

Hope you will get the issue resolved.

entry.title: Re: Breakdown analysis for equipment with no start-up dat...
entry.content:
Hello Javier Gómez,
At present, there is no configuration option in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (release 2508) that allows the Technical Object Breakdowns app to calculate results when the equipment start‑up date is blank. Even though SAP Note 3198903 states that the system should use the second notification as the start date, in practice the app requires the equipment master data to have a start‑up date maintained. I can sugguest you a workaround as mentioned below.

Maintain at least a dummy start‑up date in the equipment master record (for example, the installation date or earliest notification date).

Use variants and filters in the app to narrow down analysis once the start‑up date is set.

If you want SAP to enable the fallback logic described in the note, you would need to raise an incident with SAP Support referencing Note 3198903.

I also recommend you to always populate the equipment start‑up date in master data if you want breakdown analysis to work consistently. If this contradicts the expected behavior described in SAP documentation, open a support ticket so SAP can confirm whether this is a defect in release 2508 or an intentional design change.

Hope this workaround will help you. Please confirm if it worked

entry.title: Re: Loss of Employee Data in Candidate Profile After De-C...
entry.content:
Hi @samreen_fatima82 ,

This behaviour is standard SuccessFactors and expected:

When candidate is Internal

  • System maps Employee Profile → Candidate Profile using SM-Mapping.

  • Candidate inherits Employee ID, Rehire Status, Aadhaar etc.

When employee is Separated & becomes External

  • The Internal Candidate Profile is removed and converted back to External candidate.

  • During the De-Conversion, all Internal-only mapped fields are wiped, because:

    • SM-Mapping only works during Internal Conversion, not during De-Conversion.

    • Internal data is not stored on the External candidate object.

    • For data privacy, employee data isn't retained on an external candidate automatically.

There is no standard setting to “retain internal profile data after de-conversion.”

Feasible Solutions:

Below are the options customers typically use to retain this information.

OPTION 1 — Store the Data in Custom External Candidate Fields (Recommended)

Create custom external candidate fields (NOT internal-only fields) for:

  • Previous Employee ID

  • Previous Rehire Status

  • Previous Aadhaar Number

How it works:

  1. When internal candidate is created (Internal Conversion), SM-Mapping writes into these external fields.

  2. Because the fields belong to External Candidate entity, the values stay even after de-conversion.

Ensure your mapped fields are on the External Profile.

OPTION 2 — Use Business Rules (OnSave) to Copy Data to External Fields

Using business rules on the Candidate, you can:

  1. Create custom external fields

  2. Add a rule: OnSave of Internal candidate → copy Internal data → External fields

OPTION 3 — Use a Background Element (BC Element) That Belongs to External Profile

If you must store Aadhaar or history info:

  • Create a background element that belongs to External Candidate

  • Store internal details as history records (date-stamped)

This ensures nothing is lost during conversion.

Hope this helps!!

Thanks,

kr,

karthick.

entry.title: Automated Job Screening Using SAP Integration Suite, Adzuna, and ChatGPT
entry.content:
Idea

This exercise began as a practical way to explore SAP Integration Suite. Most job portals already provide alerts for new roles, but these alerts are usually driven by simple keyword matching. As a result, many of the recommended roles do not match the actual technical profile of the person receiving them.

The goal was to design an automated process that runs every few hours, retrieves SAP related roles from a job API, and then filters them using a model that understands a specific candidate profile. Instead of relying on keywords in the job title, the screening logic is based on how well each role aligns with a predefined set of technical strengths and preferences.

SAP Integration Suite acts as the orchestration layer. It calls the Adzuna job search API, identifies new job postings that were not seen in earlier runs, and sends each new role to a ChatGPT based classifier. That classifier has been configured using examples of roles that are a good fit and roles that are not, so its APPLY MAYBE and DO_NOT_APPLY decisions reflect the intended technical profile rather than generic matching. The integration flow then aggregates these outcomes into a single HTML formatted email with colour coding, making it easy to focus only on the roles that match that profile.


Overview

This prototype uses SAP Integration Suite to run a recurring process that retrieves SAP job postings, filters out previously seen entries, evaluates new roles with a classification model, and sends a summarized email after each run. The integration flow acts as the central engine that coordinates the API calls, manages state, and assembles the final output.

The flow begins with a scheduled trigger inside SAP Integration Suite. A set of request parameters is prepared for the Adzuna API including job keywords location and pagination details. The integration flow calls the API and receives a JSON response containing job postings for the current page.

The response is parsed to extract job attributes and job ids. A data store holds the list of job ids processed in earlier runs, and this list is used to filter out the roles already seen. Only new job entries continue through the rest of the flow.

For each new job the integration flow creates a structured input message and sends it to a ChatGPT model. The model reviews the job context and returns a category that reflects how well the role matches the defined criteria. The integration flow captures this classification and converts the job details into an HTML formatted block with colour coding.

As the run progresses, the integration flow builds a consolidated email body by appending one formatted block for each classified job. When all pages for the run have been processed or no more jobs are available, the integration flow updates the data store with the full set of seen job ids and sends the final email. If no new roles were identified during the run, the email contains a short message indicating that there were no new results.

Demo

 

Design Flow

The design flow reflects how the integration flow executes each step during a run and how the components work together.

  • A timer event triggers the integration flow at a defined schedule.
  • The integration flow prepares Adzuna request parameters including keywords location and the current page number.
  • The integration flow calls the Adzuna API and receives a JSON response.
  • A Groovy script parses the response and extracts the job details.
  • A data store entry is read to determine which job ids were processed earlier.
  • The integration flow filters the jobs and keeps only the ids that were not seen before.
  • For each new job the integration flow builds a structured classification request and sends it to the ChatGPT model.
  • The classification result is captured and formatted into an HTML block with colour coding.
  • The integration flow appends each formatted block to a single email body.
  • After all pages are processed the integration flow updates the data store with the latest job ids.
  • The integration flow sends a consolidated summary email that contains either the classified jobs or a message indicating no new results.

This design provides a repeatable cycle of fetch, filter, classify, and notify. It combines API connectivity, persistence, and model based evaluation without manual intervention.

Technical implementation

 

 

Main flow

  1. Start Timer
    A timer event triggers the flow according to the schedule. The event carries no payload. All runtime values are set in the next step.

  2. Init
    A content modifier provides the initial control values for the run. This includes
    • Adzuna request parameters such as what, what_or, where, results_per_page
    • The initial page number stored in header pagenumber
    • Technical properties such as emailBody, emailIndex, and the state entry id seen_entry_id
    These values guide the entire flow and are passed into the PageLoop.

  3. Get 1
    Reads the adzuna_state data store using the key seen_entry_id.
    If a state record exists, it contains a JSON list of previously processed job ids.
    If no record exists, the body is empty and NormalizeSeen handles that case.

  4. NormalizeSeen
    A Groovy script reads the data store body and converts it into a consistent JSON array.
    The script sets the output as a property called seen_json.
    This ensures all later steps read the stored state in the same structure regardless of whether it is the first run or a continued run.

  5. Looping Process Call 2
    Invokes the PageLoop subprocess repeatedly.
    The loop continues as long as the PageLoop sets the property hasMore to true.
    Each execution of PageLoop handles exactly one page of Adzuna results.

  6. SetMailBody
    After PageLoop finishes, the final emailBody property is moved into the message body.
    At this point emailBody contains either the full list of formatted jobs for this run or a single line stating that there were no new jobs.

  7. Mail
    Sends the email using HTML content type. The message body created in SetMailBody is delivered to the configured recipient.

PageLoop

  1. Start 1
    Receives runtime properties from the main flow such as pagenumber, results_per_page, and seen_json.
    These control how the page is fetched and how new job ids are detected.

  2. Request Reply 2
    Calls the Adzuna endpoint for the current page using
    • pagenumber
    • what and what_or keywords
    • results_per_page
    • Adzuna credentials
    The response is a JSON payload containing a list of job entries for this page.

  3. DecideAndNext
    A Groovy script that performs page processing. It
    • Parses the Adzuna JSON
    • Extracts job fields such as id, title, company, location, redirect URL, and description
    • Compares each id with the seen_json list from earlier
    • Creates a per page job queue containing only the new job entries
    • Updates seen_json to include all ids from this page
    • Determines if more pages exist based on results_per_page and the number of entries returned
    • Sets hasMore to control whether PageLoop should execute again

  4. JobLoop
    A local process that iterates over job_queue_json created by DecideAndNext.
    Each job in the queue is classified by the model.
    When job_queue_index reaches job_queue_size, JobLoop ends.

  5. PAGE STORAGE
    Writes the CSV representation of this page into the adzuna_jobs data store.
    The entry id is based on run_id and the current page number.
    This allows keeping a historical snapshot of the raw Adzuna response.

  6. SeenToBody
    A Groovy script that moves the updated seen_json into the message body.
    This prepares the body for the next data store write.

  7. STATE STORAGE
    Writes the updated seen_json list back into the adzuna_state data store under seen_entry_id.
    This allows the next scheduled run to continue with the correct state of previously processed job ids.

  8. End 1
    PageLoop finishes and returns control to the Looping Process in the main flow.
    If hasMore is true, PageLoop is invoked again for the next page.
    If hasMore is false, the loop exits.

JobLoop

  1. Start 2
    Begins with the properties populated in DecideAndNext.
    job_queue_json contains all new jobs that were found on this page.
    job_queue_index starts at zero.

  2. NextJobFromQueue
    A Groovy script that reads job_queue_json, extracts the next job based on job_queue_index, and exposes the job fields as
    one_job_id
    one_job_title
    one_job_company
    one_job_location
    one_job_description
    one_job_url
    If job_queue_index equals job_queue_size, the script signals the loop to exit.

  3. BuildChatGPTRequest
    A content modifier builds a full JSON request body using the job fields and the classification prompt.
    The structure includes system and user messages and instructs the model to return APPLY, DO_NOT_APPLY, or MAYBE.

  4. HTTP to ChatGPT
    The HTTP receiver sends the request to the OpenAI endpoint with the Authorization header set to the configured API key.
    The response contains the generated classification in the field choices[0].message.content.

  5. ExtractChatGPTResponse
    A Groovy script parses the model response, trims the content, and standardises it into one of the three valid categories.
    The output is written into the property classification.

  6. AppendToEmailBody
    A Groovy script formats the job and classification into an HTML block.
    The classification is colour coded based on the returned category.
    The block is appended to emailBody and emailIndex is incremented.

  7. BuildClassifiedRecord
    A script or content modifier builds a compact representation of the classified job.
    Common fields include id, title, company, location, classification, and redirect URL.

  8. write_adzuna_classified
    Writes the classified job into the adzuna_classified data store using id as the key.
    Overwrite is enabled so that if the same id appears again, the new classification replaces the old one.

  9. End 2
    Returns control to the JobLoop wrapper.
    If job_queue_index is less than job_queue_size, JobLoop runs again for the next job.
    If all jobs are processed, JobLoop ends and PageLoop continues with state updates.

 

ChatGPT Model:

{"messages":[
{"role":"system","content":"You are a strict classifier for a senior SAP technical professional. Their skills include ABAP, Fiori, BTP, CAP, RAP, CDS, AMDP, CPI, HANA, S4, and technical leadership. They want SAP developer, development architect, or technical lead roles, not functional or business analyst roles. When the user sends job text, respond with exactly one of these three words and nothing else: APPLY, DO_NOT_APPLY, MAYBE."},
{"role":"user","content":"Job description: SAP SuccessFactors functional consultant focusing on employee central and talent modules. The role is focused on HR processes and configuration rather than technical development."},
{"role":"assistant","content":"DO_NOT_APPLY"}
]}

{"messages":[
{"role":"system","content":"You are a strict classifier for a senior SAP technical professional. Their skills include ABAP, Fiori, BTP, CAP, RAP, CDS, AMDP, CPI, HANA, S4, and technical leadership. They want SAP developer, development architect, or technical lead roles, not functional or business analyst roles. When the user sends job text, respond with exactly one of these three words and nothing else: APPLY, DO_NOT_APPLY, MAYBE."},
{"role":"user","content":"Job description: Senior SAP BTP architect focusing on CAP, RAP, CDS, event driven integration, and leading a team of developers."},
{"role":"assistant","content":"APPLY"}
]}

This is a fine tuning training sample for an OpenAI model. Each line in the JSONL file represents one supervised example. It contains a system instruction, a user input, and the expected assistant output.

The system message defines the rules for classification, the user message contains a job description, and the assistant message holds the correct category. A full training file contains many such examples, which helps the model learn how to consistently return the categories APPLY, DO_NOT_APPLY, or MAYBE.

Result

Jobs are classified according to the profile.

References

Adzuna Job Search API: https://developer.adzuna.com/activedocs#!/adzuna/search

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/cpi-gmail-smtp-integration/ba-p/13457193

Conclusion

This prototype shows how SAP Integration Suite an external job search API and a classification model can work together to create a repeatable automated process. The integration flow retrieves new SAP roles filters out previously seen entries evaluates each role through a lightweight model and sends a clear summary after every run. It gives a practical example of scheduled processing state management and controlled use of generative AI inside an integration flow.

The exercise helped in understanding how the integration flow behaves when combined with external APIs and model based logic and how small design adjustments influence stability and accuracy. It shows how integration tools and AI techniques can complement each other in a simple and maintainable way.

Disclaimer

This is a prototype created for learning purposes. Functional gaps and bugs may exist. SAP guidelines best practices coding standards authorisation requirements and performance considerations were not in scope. A real solution would require proper error handling security checks resilience measures and alignment with enterprise development standards.

entry.title: Re: Change the procurement type from E to F
entry.content:
Hi,
if you are changing the procurement type in SAP MM Transaction OMD9 (from E = In-house production to F = External procurement) will not impact existing material masters. It only affects the default procurement type for new material masters created in the future under that material type. Existing materials retain whatever procurement type was set in their master data unless you manually update them.

entry.title: Re: MMAM tcode in test mode
entry.content:
Hi,
You cannot rollback after the call transaction because, the transaction MMAM (Change Material Type) contains its own COMMIT WORK. When you use CALL TRANSACTION or batch input, that commit is executed inside the transaction itself. Once the commit is executed, the LUW (Logical Unit of Work) is closed, and you cannot roll it back from your report program. That’s why your attempt to wrap it in your own rollback logic fails — the database changes are already persisted. Unfortunately, you cannot override SAP’s commit behavior in standard transactions.

One thing is possible if you use BAPIs or function modules instead of MMAM.
Many SAP transactions have underlying BAPIs or function modules that perform the same logic but leave commit control to the caller. For material master changes, find BAPI BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA (general material changes) BAPI_MATERIAL_MAINTAINDATA (more flexible, newer)

These BAPIs do not commit automatically. You can call them multiple times, then decide whether to COMMIT WORK or ROLLBACK WORK.

This can be one workaround. Let me know if you need any more suggestion

entry.title: Create code list restriction in SAP Sales , Service and Enterprise Service Management
entry.content:
Code list restrictions are a key part of keeping data clean in SAP CX systems. They work by making sure a specific field only accepts values from a predefined list. This is incredibly helpful for standardizing how information is entered and ensuring consistency across your entire organization. In this post, we'll walk through exactly how to set these restrictions up and put them to work in SAP CX Systems.

Code list restrictions can be divided into two types.

  • Instance based code list restriction.
  • Role based code list restriction.

Instance based code list restriction.

In instance based code list restriction , if you want to restrict any code list with some control field you can use instance based code list restriction.

  • You define a restricted field (the code list to be restricted)
  • You specify a controlling field that determines which values are available
  • When users select a value in the controlling field, only relevant options appear in the restricted field

Example - If you want to control Cash discount term code with the Distribution channel you can choose code to restrict field as 

Cash discount term code and control field as Distribution channel.

Role based code list restriction

In role based code list restriction you can restrict code list based on the user roles.

  • You define which values are appropriate for specific user roles
  • The system checks the logged-in user's role assignments
  • Only values permitted for the user's roles are displayed in the selection options

Example- You can control Case type based on the logged in user role.

Help link- https://help.sap.com/docs/CX_NG_SVC/56436b4e8fa84dc8b4408c7795a012c4/fb2b10068bf446778fe65eb539133b37.html

entry.title: How S/4HANA Finance Improves Working Capital and Cash Flow Forecasting
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Finance is designed to meet this demand. With a unified data model, real-time analytics, and embedded machine learning, S/4HANA allows organizations to optimize cash flows, shorten the cash conversion cycle, and generate more reliable short- and long-term forecasts. This article explains how S/4HANA Finance enhances working capital management and elevates liquidity forecasting to a strategic level.

Understanding Working Capital in the S/4HANA Context

Working capital represents the liquidity a company needs to run daily operations and typically revolves around three core areas:

  • Accounts Receivable (AR)
  • Accounts Payable (AP)
  • Inventory

Traditional ERP systems treat these components in separate modules, which leads to fragmented data, manual reconciliations, and delays in visibility. Forecasts often rely on spreadsheets, batch jobs, and outdated data.

S/4HANA changes this paradigm with its Universal Journal, which consolidates financial, controlling, asset, and material ledger data into a single real-time table (ACDOCA). This eliminates reconciliation gaps and allows finance teams to analyze working capital KPIs instantly, based on the latest actuals.

Key S/4HANA Finance Features That Transform Working Capital Management

1. Universal Journal (ACDOCA): One Source of Truth

The Universal Journal is the structural backbone of S/4HANA Finance. Instead of posting to multiple tables, the system records all financial and controlling details in a single line item.

This creates several advantages:

  • Real-time visibility into receivables, payables, and inventory values
  • Instant KPI calculation (DSO, DPO, DIO, cash conversion cycle)
  • No batch jobs or reconciliation between FI and CO
  • Faster month-end closing cycles

With unified data, AR aging, AP commitments, and inventory levels are always up to date—giving finance teams the foundation needed for accurate working capital optimization.

  1. Real-Time Analytics & Embedded Fiori Apps

S/4HANA enables finance users to track working capital trends through pre-built Fiori apps and embedded analytics. These tools provide interactive, drill-down dashboards for:

  • Overdue receivables
  • Collection effectiveness
  • Payables due within a specific period
  • Supplier liabilities and payment block analysis
  • Material inventory aging
  • Cash discount utilization

Having access to real-time analytics allows business leaders to act faster and with more precision. For example, AR teams can prioritize high-risk customers, while procurement teams can renegotiate terms with suppliers who consistently affect DPO.

  1. Integration Across Finance, Sales, Procurement & Inventory

Working capital management is not only a finance responsibility—it touches end-to-end business processes:

  • Order-to-Cash (OTC) influences receivables and DSO
  • Procure-to-Pay (P2P) determines payables, DPO, and cash disbursement timing
  • Manufacturing and inventory directly affect stock levels and DIO

S/4HANA integrates these processes natively. Finance teams no longer need to gather data across modules or rely on operational teams for manual updates. Instead, S/4HANA provides a consolidated view of all working capital drivers, enabling data-driven decisions that reduce the cash conversion cycle.

  1. Embedded Machine Learning for Collections and Credit Management

One of the biggest working capital challenges is unpredictable customer payment behavior. S/4HANA addresses this with machine-learning-powered scoring models that improve:

  • Payment date prediction
  • Dunning prioritization
  • Dispute resolution
  • Credit risk assessment

ML algorithms analyze historical transactions and customer habits to forecast when invoices will likely be paid. As a result, AR teams can focus their efforts on accounts that significantly affect liquidity. Better collections performance directly improves working capital and reduces reliance on credit lines.

How S/4HANA Finance Enhances Cash Flow Forecasting

Cash flow forecasting remains one of the most strategic activities in corporate finance. However, many organizations still rely on static spreadsheets and delayed financial data. S/4HANA Finance replaces this manual approach with real-time liquidity insights.

1. Real-Time Cash Position & Liquidity Planning

The updated Cash Management module in S/4HANA provides:

  • Cash Position: short-term cash visibility based on actual bank balances, open items, and expected incoming/outgoing payments
  • Liquidity Forecast: mid-term visibility incorporating sales orders, purchase orders, planned investments, and recurring payments

These views allow treasury teams to understand liquidity needs and avoid unnecessary borrowing or inefficient cash sitting idle.

2. Treasury Integration for Holistic Liquidity Management

S/4HANA integrates seamlessly with SAP Treasury and Risk Management (TRM), enabling companies to include treasury exposures—such as loans, FX hedges, derivatives, and interest payments—directly in liquidity forecasts.

The One Exposure from Operations framework consolidates:

  • AR and AP
  • Bank statements
  • Treasury transactions
  • FX and commodity exposures
  • In-house cash positions

This unified approach ensures liquidity forecasts reflect all cash movements across the business.

3. Predictive Analytics & Machine Learning-Enhanced Forecasts

S/4HANA Finance and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) can apply predictive models to estimate future cash flows based on:

  • Historical patterns
  • Seasonality
  • Customer payment behavior
  • Supplier payment trends
  • Sales cycles
  • Market conditions

Machine learning continuously refines these predictions, improving forecast accuracy over time and providing early warnings when liquidity risks emerge.

4. Bank Communication & Real-Time Reconciliation

S/4HANA supports API-based bank communication, replacing manual statement uploads or batch processes. Real-time bank integration improves:

  • Visibility of actual bank balances
  • Automation of reconciliations
  • Cash concentration processes
  • Liquidity categorization

Because cash balances update continuously, forecasts remain accurate throughout the day.

Practical Use Cases and Business Impact

Use Case 1: Reduced DSO Through Predictive Collections

A manufacturing company using S/4HANA’s ML-based payment prediction identifies customers at high risk of late payment. The AR team prioritizes those accounts for dunning and personalized follow-up.

Impact:

  • Lower DSO
  • Improved cash inflows
  • Stronger working capital position

Use Case 2: Optimizing AP to Improve DPO

With S/4HANA’s real-time AP analysis, a global distributor identifies suppliers who consistently offer favorable cash terms but whose invoices are being paid early. The organization adjusts payment runs accordingly.

Impact:

  • DPO increases
  • Reduced early payment leakage
  • Improved short-term liquidity

Use Case 3: Inventory Right-Sizing

An international retailer uses S/4HANA’s integration between materials management and finance to track inventory carrying costs and aging in real time. Procurement adjusts safety stock levels and reduces slow-moving items.

Impact:

  • Lower inventory carrying costs
  • Better capital utilization
  • Shorter cash conversion cycle

Use Case 4: Real-Time Liquidity Forecast for CFOs

A multinational company consolidates all global entities into S/4HANA’s Cash Management and Treasury modules. CFOs receive a real-time forecast of liquidity across currencies, banks, and regions.

Impact:

  • Strategic optimization of borrowing and investment
  • Faster decision-making for hedging and cash pooling
  • Reduced risk exposure

Implementation Considerations

To maximize the benefits of S/4HANA for working capital and liquidity management, organizations should consider:

1. Clean and Consistent Master Data

Accurate customer, vendor, and material master data directly impacts AR, AP, and inventory visibility. Data quality initiatives are essential.

2. Use of SAP Analytics Cloud (Optional but Recommended)

For advanced planning, simulation, and predictive analytics, SAC offers extended forecasting capabilities.

3. Organizational Alignment

Working capital touches multiple departments. Aligning finance, sales, procurement, supply chain, and treasury is critical.

4. Training on Fiori Apps and Real-Time Dashboards

Even the most sophisticated tools require strong user adoption. Teams should be trained to make full use of S/4HANA’s analytics and automation features.

Conclusion

S/4HANA Finance transforms working capital and cash flow forecasting from manual, reactive processes into dynamic, real-time capabilities. With its unified data model, embedded analytics, automation features, and machine learning enhancements, S/4HANA empowers finance teams to make faster, more informed decisions that strengthen liquidity, reduce operational risk, and improve overall financial performance.

For CFOs and finance leaders looking to build resilience and agility, S/4HANA Finance is not just an upgrade—it is a strategic enabler for modern working capital excellence.

Everyone will move to SAP S/4HANA and one major improvement S/4HANA brings is the luxury of using Flexible Workflow. This Blog will help you  Find Standard Flexible Workflows and which ones are already Activated in your system.

Login to SAP and Enter Transaction Code SE16H

Enter View SWFACTSCENSHLP

Now again go to Transacrion Code SE16H and enter --> IVWFTMPLSCENVHB and select Group by Application Component and Execute or F8

entry.title: Meet the Latest in SAP Fieldglass XSL Templates: The Detail Time Sheet Edition
entry.content:
Hey there, SAP Fieldglass Enthusiasts! Let us introduce you to the latest addition to our collection of XSL templates: the Detail Time Sheet XSL Template!

You might remember our first blog post about our XSL templates. No? That’s not a problem! We’ve got it right here, handy for you: Transform Your Document Management: Unleash SAP Fieldglass XSL Templates. But today, we’re thrilled to present this fresh template, designed to add clarity, consistency, and ease to your business workflow.

The Detail Time Sheet XSL template was specifically planned to mirror the exact structure and data that users see on-screen. Imagine having your PDF outputs match precisely to the user interface, leading to improved clarity and usability. No more guesswork or discrepancies between dynamic and static formats. Whether for internal reviews, client meetings, or record keeping, this feature ensures your documents are both professional and reliable.

Check out all the XSL templates SAP Fieldglass has to offer and how to set them up in the XSL Template – Setup Guide for Buyers and Suppliers. And if you’ve got any questions, check the XSL Template – FAQ.

Whether you’re a long-time user of SAP Fieldglass XSL templates or just starting to explore their potential, this new addition is an upgrade to how you manage and interpret your data. Let it simplify your operations and enhance your document accuracy.
